title: TaxSEA
text: TaxSEA R package designed enable rapid interpretation differential abundance analysis correlation analysis output microbiota data. TaxSEA takes input vector genus species names rank. example log2 fold changes, Spearman’s rho. TaxSEA uses Kolmogorov-Smirnov test identify particular group species genera (.e. set taxa butyrate producers) skewed one end distribution . Simply put, TaxSEA allows users rapidly go list species metabolite producers altered, findings similar previously published study.

title: Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis
text: Traditional differential abundance (DA) analysis looks individual microbes going . sounds sensible human microbiome studies often falls apart everyone’s microbiome unique, species shared across people. TaxSEA doesn’t seem test individual species different rather group species shared characteristic different. example seeing shift bugs increased oxygen tolerance, increase bugs produce certain metabolite enzyme, even seeing change bugs known disease association humans. want know check paper, find approach far reproducible standard DA analysis well capable extracting biologically meaningful patterns. TaxSEA can also test differences particular taxonomic rank. example instead just summing species genus. see distribution species within genus different groups. short, TaxSEA makes easy intepret changes microbiome data. TaxSEA takes input vector genus species names rank. example log2 fold changes Spearman’s rho. TaxSEA uses Kolmogorov-Smirnov test identify particular group species genera (.e. set taxa butyrate producers) skewed one end distribution. Note: Although TaxSEA principle can applied microbiome data source, databases utilized largely cover human associated microbiomes human gut microbiome particular. TaxSEA likely perform best human gut microbiome data.

title: Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis
text: addition taxon sets defined function phenotype, users can define sets based taxonomy. Current methods test higher taxonomic levels (e.g., genus family), involve aggregating counts approach opposing shifts individual species may cancel , obscuring meaningful biological patterns. instance, antibiotic treatment may suppress certain species allowing resistant species within genus expand occupy vacant niche, creating ecological shift appears net change broader taxonomic levels. utilise data Chng et al. demonstrating comparison Atopic dermatitis controls.
code: #### Applying TaxSEA functionality to taxonomic ranks   # This script applies TaxSEA to identify taxonomic enrichment at different taxonomic levels. # Specifically, we analyze enrichment at the family level using metagenomic data  # Load required libraries library(TaxSEA) library(curatedMetagenomicData) library(tidyverse) library(phyloseq) library(MicrobiomeStat) library(dplyr)  # Load sample metadata metadata_all <- sampleMetadata  # Filter metadata for the specific study (ChngKR_2016) metadata <- metadata_all %>%    filter(study_name == "ChngKR_2016") %>%    column_to_rownames('sample_id')  # Extract count data using curatedMetagenomicData cmd_data <- curatedMetagenomicData(   pattern = "ChngKR_2016.relative_abundance",   counts = TRUE,   dryrun = FALSE )  # Convert the extracted data to a count matrix counts_data <- assay(cmd_data[[1]]) counts_data <- counts_data[, rownames(metadata)]  # Subset to relevant samples  # Filter taxa with at least one sample having counts > 100 counts_data <- counts_data[apply(counts_data > 100, 1, sum) > 0, ]  # Extract species names from taxonomic strings species_names <- gsub("s__", "", sapply(rownames(counts_data), function(y) strsplit(y, "\\|")[[1]][7])) rownames(counts_data) <- species_names  # Create a taxonomic lineage dataframe # Remove taxonomic prefixes (k__, p__, c__, etc.) and separate into taxonomic ranks  # make data frame of taxon lineages taxon_lineages <- data.frame(Name = species_names,                              Lineage = names(species_names)) %>%   mutate(Lineage = str_remove_all(Lineage, '[kpcofgs]__')) %>%   separate(col = Lineage, into = c('kingdom', 'phylum', 'class',                                     'order', 'family', 'genus', 'species'),             sep = '\\|') %>%   mutate(name = Name) %>%   remove_rownames() %>%   column_to_rownames('name')  # Perform differential abundance testing using LinDA metadata$study_condition <- factor(metadata$study_condition, levels = c("control", "AD"))  linda_results <- linda(   feature.dat = counts_data,   meta.dat = metadata,   formula = '~study_condition',   feature.dat.type = 'count',   prev.filter = 0.05 )  # Extract log2 fold change values for differential taxa linda_results <- linda_results$output$study_conditionAD log2_fold_changes <- linda_results$log2FoldChange names(log2_fold_changes) <- rownames(linda_results)  # Define the taxonomic rank for enrichment analysis selected_taxon_level <- 'genus'  # Modify as needed (e.g., genus, phylum)  # Create a named list of species grouped by taxonomic rank custom_taxon_sets <- taxon_lineages %>%   group_by(.data[[selected_taxon_level]]) %>%    summarise(species = list(species), .groups = "drop") %>%   deframe()  # Perform enrichment analysis using TaxSEA custom_taxsea_results <- TaxSEA(taxon_ranks = log2_fold_changes, custom_db = custom_taxon_sets) custom_taxsea_results <- custom_taxsea_results$custom_sets
